request.prompt:

Der Artikel soll etwa 1 Seite lang sein und mit Markdown formatiert sein. Der Titel soll nicht im Artikel enthalten sein, der Artikel soll direkt mit dem ersten Absatz beginnen. F√ºge ein <!--more--> zwischen dem ersten und zweiten Absatz ein.
Verwende dabei nur Informationen der letzten 7 Tage, sodass der Artikel nur die aktuellen Neuigkeiten zu dem Thema enth√§lt.
F√ºge am Ende des Artikels einen Absatz mit den verlinkten Quellen hinzu.

Mira Murati, the former CTO of OpenAI, has raised $2 billion for her new AI venture, _Thinking Machines Lab_, just six months after launching it. The eye-popping round values the company at $10 billion‚Äîan unusually high number for a startup still in its early stages.

The deal, [first reported](https://www.ft.com/content/9edc67e6-96a9-4d2b-820d-57bc1279e358) by the _Financial Times_, is one of the largest seed rounds in Silicon Valley history. ### Andrew Barker

Whatever it is that ex-OpenAI exec¬†[Mira Murati](https://www.linkedin.com/in/mira-murati-4b39a066/)¬†is building, it certainly seems to have gotten investors to open their wallets. Murati's Thinking Machines Lab has closed a $2 billion seed funding round, according to an anonymously-sourced¬†[Financial Times report](https://www.ft.com/content/9edc67e6-96a9-4d2b-820d-57bc1279e358), valuing the artificial intelligence startup at roughly $10 billion. The¬†[nascent company](https://www.linkedin.com/news/story/ex-openai-exec-unveils-new-venture-6311940/)¬†led by OpenAI's former chief technology officer has¬†[recruited](https://thinkingmachines.ai/)¬†other top alumni including John Schulman and¬†[Barret Zoph](https://www.linkedin.com/in/barret-zoph-65990543/).

What stands out is not just the size of the raise‚Äîpotentially the largest seed round ever‚Äîbut how quickly a relatively secretive company can command such investor confidence based on a founder‚Äôs track record and team. Thinking Machines, the secretive AI startup founded by OpenAI‚Äôs former chief technology officer Mira Murati, has reportedly raised $2 billion at a $10 billion valuation.. =========================================

Breaking: Mira Murati‚Äôs AI Startup ‚ÄúThinking Machines Lab‚Äù Secures $2 Billion,Valued at $10 Billion
===================================================================================================

San Francisco,CA ‚Äì in a stunning development in the artificial intelligence landscape,Thinking Machines Lab,the secretive AI startup founded by former OpenAI Chief [technology](https://www.archyde.com/category/technology/) Officer Mira Murati,has reportedly finalized a staggering $2 billion seed funding round. This investment values the mere six-month-old entity at an remarkable $10 billion, marking one of the largest seed rounds in history. The AI startup is making waves across the tech industry.

Massive Investment Fuels Speculation and Excitement
---------------------------------------------------

While the specific projects undertaken by Thinking Machines Lab remain shrouded in mystery, the company‚Äôs ability to attract such meaningful investment underscores the considerable reputation of Murati and the high-profile AI researchers who have joined her team. Andreessen Horowitz spearheaded the round, with notable participation from Conviction Partners, led by Sarah Guo.

Murati‚Äôs Departure from OpenAI

Murati‚Äôs departure from OpenAI occurred in September of last year, after she played a pivotal role in developing some of the company‚Äôs most recognizable AI products, including ChatGPT, DALL-E, and the increasingly popular voice mode. Several of her former colleagues from OpenAI, including co-founder John Schulman, have as joined her at Thinking Machines Lab.

A Leader‚Äôs Stand and a New Beginning
------------------------------------

notably, Murati was among a group of executives who voiced concerns regarding Sam Altman‚Äôs leadership at OpenAI in 2023. Following altman‚Äôs brief ousting by the board in November of that year, Murati stepped in as interim CEO before Altman was rapidly reinstated.

The Murati Effect: Why Investors are Betting Big on This AI Startup
-------------------------------------------------------------------

What makes Thinking Machines Lab so appealing to investors? The combination of Murati‚Äôs proven track record in AI innovation, the pedigree of her team, and the general excitement surrounding advancements in artificial intelligence have created a perfect storm of investor enthusiasm.

**Did You No?** Seed funding is the initial capital used to start a company, frequently enough coming from angel investors or venture capitalists.A $2 billion seed round

Her secretive AI startup Thinking Machines Lab just closed a $2 billion seed round at a $10 billion valuation ‚Äî without revealing what the company actually builds..

Former OpenAI CTO Mira Murati Raises $2B for Thinking Machines at $10B valuation
================================================================================

*   [](/author/chris/)

[Chris McKay](/author/chris/)

June 20, 2025 ‚Ä¢ 2 min read

 

Six months after leaving OpenAI, Mira Murati has pulled off one of the most audacious fundraising stunts in Silicon Valley history. Her secretive AI startup Thinking Machines Lab just closed a $2 billion seed round at a $10 billion valuation ‚Äî without revealing what the company actually builds.

**Key Points**

*   Six-month-old Thinking Machines is now worth $10 billion.
*   A16z is headlining the $2 billion round; minimum ticket size is $50 million.
*   Murati has lured ex-OpenAI heavyweights like John Schulman and Bob McGrew.

The deal shows just how much investor appetite exists for proven AI talent, even when that talent won't say what they're working on. According to people familiar with the transaction, some funds passed on the opportunity precisely because Murati's pitch offered no information about products or financial plans. But Andreessen Horowitz and others were willing to bet big on her track record ‚Äî and what a track record it is.

During her six years at OpenAI, Murati led development of ChatGPT, DALL-E, and the code-writing system Codex. When the board briefly ousted Sam Altman last November, she stepped in as interim CEO. Her departure in September came amid a broader exodus that's now regrouped under her leadership, including OpenAI co-founder John Schulman, who bounced from OpenAI to Anthropic and now to Thinking Machines in less than a year.

The funding structure gives Murati unusual control ‚Äî she holds board voting rights that outweigh all other directors combined. That's remarkable for a six-month-old company with no disclosed products. But it's not unprecedented in today's AI landscape. [Safe Superintelligence](https://www.maginative.com/article/safe-superintelligence-in-talks-for-20-billion-valuation-despite-no-revenue/), co-founded by former OpenAI chief scientist Ilya Sutskever, raised $2 billion at a $32 billion valuation without shipping anything either.

The $2 billion figure puts Thinking Machines in rarified company. For context, OpenAI itself raised $6.6 billion in October at a $157 billion valuation, while Elon Musk's xAI has pulled in two separate $6 billion rounds this year. But those companies at least have products in market and revenue to show for their efforts.

According to people briefed on the matter, Thinking Machines is working on artificial general intelligence ‚Äî the hypothetical point where AI systems match or exceed human cognitive abilities across all domains. It's the same goal pursued by OpenAI, Anthropic, Google's DeepMind, and virtually every other major AI lab.

The secrecy strategy might actually be strategic. In an industry where technical details can provide competitive advantages to rivals, keeping quiet until you have something substantial to show makes sense. Both OpenAI and Anthropic were similarly secretive in their early days, revealing their capabilities only when ready to deploy them.

But the approach also carries risks. Building AGI requires massive computational resources, specialized talent, and years of research with uncertain outcomes. Even with $2 billion in the bank, the company will need to show progress relatively quickly to justify its valuation and attract follow-on funding.

For investors, this represents a classic Silicon Valley bet: that the people who built today's leading AI systems can do it again, potentially better. With AI's market potential measured in trillions and talent being the scarcest resource, that may be a calculated risk worth taking.

For now, though, Murati has bought herself something invaluable in the fast-moving AI world: time and resources to build without the pressure of immediately

result.content:
Mira Murati, die ehemalige CTO von OpenAI, hat f√ºr ihr neues KI-Unternehmen Thinking Machines Lab beeindruckende 2 Milliarden Dollar gesammelt. Nur sechs Monate nach der Gr√ºndung wird das Unternehmen nun mit 10 Milliarden Dollar bewertet. Diese Finanzierungsrunde, die von Andreessen Horowitz angef√ºhrt wurde, ist eine der gr√∂√üten Seed-Runden in der Geschichte des Silicon Valley und hat das urspr√ºngliche Ziel von 1 Milliarde Dollar verdoppelt.

<!--more-->

Thinking Machines Lab, das im Februar 2025 aus dem Stealth-Modus hervorging, hat seitdem gro√ües Interesse geweckt, vor allem aufgrund von Muratis beeindruckender Erfolgsbilanz und der hochkar√§tigen Talente, die sie an Bord geholt hat. Das Unternehmen konzentriert sich auf die Entwicklung von KI-Systemen, die breiter einsetzbar und sicherer sind als bestehende L√∂sungen. Zu den prominenten Investoren geh√∂ren neben Andreessen Horowitz auch Conviction Partners unter der Leitung von Sarah Guo.

Muratis Abgang von OpenAI im September letzten Jahres war von internen Spannungen gepr√§gt, insbesondere nach der kurzzeitigen Absetzung von Sam Altman durch den Vorstand. Murati √ºbernahm damals vor√ºbergehend die Rolle der CEO, bevor Altman wieder eingesetzt wurde. Ihre neue Firma hat bereits mehrere ehemalige OpenAI-Mitarbeiter, darunter Mitbegr√ºnder John Schulman, angezogen.

Die Geheimhaltungstaktik von Thinking Machines Lab k√∂nnte strategisch sein. In einer Branche, in der technische Details einen Wettbewerbsvorteil bieten k√∂nnen, macht es Sinn, bis zur Marktreife still zu bleiben. Diese Strategie birgt jedoch auch Risiken, da die Entwicklung von k√ºnstlicher allgemeiner Intelligenz (AGI) enorme Ressourcen und Zeit erfordert. Trotz der 2 Milliarden Dollar in der Bank muss das Unternehmen bald Fortschritte zeigen, um seine Bewertung zu rechtfertigen und weitere Investitionen anzuziehen.

F√ºr Investoren ist dies eine klassische Wette des Silicon Valley: dass die Menschen, die die f√ºhrenden KI-Systeme von heute entwickelt haben, dies erneut tun k√∂nnen, m√∂glicherweise sogar besser. Mit einem Marktpotenzial, das in Billionen gemessen wird, und Talent als knappste Ressource, k√∂nnte dies ein kalkuliertes Risiko sein, das sich lohnt.

### Quellen
